captions.text:
>> WELCOME BACK! MY GUEST
TONIGHT,

HE STARS IN HBO'S "GAME OF
THRONES", IT'S ABOUT TO
PREMIER ITS FIFTH SEASON.

>> YOU NEVER TOLD ME WHY YOU SET
ME FREE.
>> YOUR BROTHER ASKED ME TO.
>> YOU COULD HAVE SAID NO.

>> REFUSING THE KINGSLAYER
IS A DANGEROUS PROPOSITION.

>> NOT AS DANGEROUS AS RELEASING
ME. YOU RISKED YOUR LIFE,

YOUR POSITION, EVERYTHING,
WHY?  YOU ARE NOT FAMILY.
YOU OWE ME NOTHING.
>> I DIDN'T DO IT FOR YOU.
I DID IT FOR THE SEVEN KINGDOMS.

>> DRUNKEN DWARF WILL NEVER BE
THE SAVIOR OF THE SEVEN
KINGDOMS.

>> I DON'T BELIEVE IN SAVIORS, I
BELIEVE MEN OF TALENT HAVE A
PART TO PLAY IN THE WAR TO COME.
>> Jon: KILL HIM!

PLEASE WELCOME BACK TO THE
PROGRAM, PETER DINKLAGE!
[ CHEERS AND APPLAUSE ]
[ CHEERS AND APPLAUSE ]

>> HOW DID YOU GET THAT
STUDENT FILM I DID YEARS AGO?

>> Jon: IT WAS SENT TO US BY
SOME ANONYMOUS --
>> THAT WAS MY OWN WARDROBE.
>> Jon: WAS IT REALLY?
>> YEAH.

>> Jon: IT SEEMS VERY
COMFORTABLE.
>> Jon: WAS THAT SUEDE?
>> YES. AND CASHMERE.
>> Jon: IT WAS BEAUTIFUL.
>> YEAH.

>> Jon: HERE IS A TRIBUTE TO
YOUR CHARACTER.

THERE IS NOT A MOMENT THAT I
WANT YOUR CHARACTER TO --
>> TO DIE.

>> Jon: NO LIKE HE IS GOING TO
HIT THAT GUY IN THE HEAD WITH
THE BOTTLE.
>> YEAH.

>> Jon: LIKE I JUST ALWAYS THINK
THAT YOU HAVE SOMETHING GOING.

>> THAT'S TRUE. LIKE BENNY HILL?
LIKE --

>> Jon:  NOT HIT HIM IN THE
HEAD LIKE -- I MEAN HIT HIM

IN THE HEAD, LIKE YOU LIKE TAKE
A SIP OF IT AND LIKE IT TURNS

OUT TO BE LIKE FLAME POISON OR
SOMETHING LIKE THAT.
>> RIGHT.
>> Jon: LIKE DRAGON POISON.
>> YEAH. I WISH.
BECAUSE I DRINK SO MUCH OF THAT.
>> Jon: ON THE SHOW?
>> WINE ON THE SHOW.

>> Jon: YOU KNOW, THE
SERIES NOW, IT VEERS A

LITTLE BIT AWAY FROM THE
BOOKS NOW, A LITTLE MORE --
>> IN A LOT OF WAYS, YES.
>> Jon: A LOT OF WAYS.

>> IN MANY WAYS, YES. A LOT OF
PEOPLE --

>> Jon: I WAS SURPRISED TO SEE
FOR INSTANCE, THERE IS NOW A BOY
WIZARD NAMED HARRY IN IT.

WHICH SEEMED A BIT OF A
DEPARTURE.
>> YEAH. YEAH.

THE WHOLE SEASON THIS YEAR IS IN
A RESTAURANT LIKE
"MY DINNER WITH ANDRE."

>> Jon: JUST YOU TWO SITTING
THERE TALKING.
>> JUST THE WHOLE TIME.

>> Jon: DOES, DOES GEORGE, DOES
HE EVER LIKE STOP BY AND BE LIKE
NO!
>> HE USED TO.
HE IS BUSY LATELY.
>> Jon: YEAH.
>> HE IS WRITING THOSE BOOKS.
RIGHT?

I MEAN, MY HEART GOES
OUT TO GEORGE, BECAUSE BOY OH
BOY --
>> Jon: THAT'S A LOT.

>> THEY'RE JUST, THEY'RE HARD ON
HIM, THE FANS.

I MEAN, IT IS LOVELY BECAUSE
THEY WANT, THEY WANT THOSE

BOOKS, BUT, HEY, THEY HAVE
GOT TO EASE UP.

>> Jon: YOU KNOW WHAT IT IS TOO,
I THINK THAT THERE IS AN

INSATIABILITY AND ONCE PEOPLE
GET AHOLD OF IT LIKE, THEY DON'T

REALIZE THE PROCESS, LIKE
IT TAKES A LONG TIME,
AND A LOT OF ENERGY.
>> YEAH.

>> Jon: TO CREATE THAT AND
WEAVE THOSE, AND THEY'RE VERY

COMPLEX AND VERY VIVID AND VERY
EXPLICIT.
>> YEAH.

>> Jon: I IMAGINE THAT IS
DIFFICULT OR DO YOU THINK DOES

HE HAVE LIKE JUST A TEAM
OF LITTLE MINI MARTINS THAT ARE

JUST IN THE BACK ROOM JUST LIKE
-- JUST POUNDING AWAY?
>> PROBABLY.
>> Jon: YEAH.

>> DON'T WE ALL HAVE THOSE?  YOU
HAVE THOSE.

>> Jon: WELL --
>> RIGHT?

>> Jon: WE CALLED THEM
INDENTURED SERVANTS.
>> THEY ARE CALLED INTERNS.

>> Jon: THAT'S RIGHT. THEY'RE
CALLED --

DO YOU GUYS, DO THEY, I
TELL YOU THE --

>> YOU GUYS LAUGH
WHEN I SAY INTERNS.

I COULD SAY ANYTHING. IT'S
VERY LOVELY. YOU'RE SO SWEET.

>> Jon: TRY IT. TRY A WORD. JUST
TRY IT.
>> CATERPILLAR.
>> Jon: COME ON.

YOU WENT RIGHT TO CATERPILLAR?
THAT'S A FUNNY WORD!
THAT'S AN EXCELLENT CHOICE!

ARE PEOPLE GONNA, YOU KNOW, I AM
ALWAYS CONCERNED WHEN SOMETHING

LIKE THIS HAPPENS THAT
TELEVISION JUMPS ON IT AND --
>> WHAT DO WE DO NOW.

>> Jon: CREATES, YES OR
CREATES BAD VERSIONS OF
THIS SIMILAR --

>> I THINK THERE HAVE BEEN A LOT
OF BAD VERSIONS BEFORE US.
>> Jon: RIGHT, RIGHT, RIGHT.

>> YOU KNOW, BECAUSE IT IS
REALLY HARD TO DO.

IT COSTS MONEY AND TV USED TO
NOT BE WHAT IT IS TODAY.

>> Jon: IT'S ALSO HARD I THINK
TO KEEP IT FROM BECOMING

PARODY. I THINK THAT'S THE MOST
DIFFICULT THING.

>> WE OFTEN MAKE IT PARODY ON
SET.

>> Jon: THE CHRISTMAS PARTY I
AM SURE GETS VERY --
>> OH, IT IS SUCH A FINE LINE.
IT IS SUCH A FINE LINE.

>> Jon: YES. BUT TO PULL THAT IS
NOT EASY.
>> NO.

AND WE'RE, I MEAN, ESPECIALLY
WORKING WITH CONLETH HILL,

WHO PLAYS VARYS, THE SPIDER, THE
BALD MAN IN THAT SCENE.

>> Jon: HE GETS A LITTLE, HE GET
INTO IT. YOU KNOW WHO ELSE?

>> NO, I MEAN, HE'S IT IS SO
MUCH FUN.

>> Jon: HOW'S MOUNTAIN? HOW'S
THE, HE --

>> THAT MAN, WE WERE HAVING
DINNER, I GOT TO EAT DINNER WITH

HIM ONE NIGHT IN CROATIA AND HE
ORDERED SEVEN CHICKENS.
HE ATE SEVEN CHICKENS.

LIKE WHOLE CHICKENS, LIKE
ROAST CHICKENS.
>> Jon: OH, SO THEY WERE COOKED?
>> YEAH.
>> Jon: THAT'S --
>> YEAH.

>> Jon: BUT HE, LIKE YOU READ
ABOUT --

>> JUST AN AMAZING
LOVELY GUY.
GIANT, HUGE.
>> Jon: HUGE. AND I READ --
>> YEAH. HE LIFTS STONES.
>> Jon: RIGHT.
>> HE BROKE -- THIS IS TRUE.

HE BROKE A 1,400-YEAR-OLD
STRENGTH RECORD.
>> YEAH.

>> Jon: BY LIFTING -- I THINK
HE PUT IT ON HIS SHOULDER, A
30-FOOT TREE TRUNK.
>> YEAH.

>> Jon: AND LIKE CARRYING IT
TO A 7-11.
>> TO HIS GIRLFRIEND.

>> Jon: I DON'T KNOW WHAT THE
END WAS.
>> YEAH. YEAH.

>> Jon: DOES HE JUST PICK
THINGS UP LIKE A FLINTSTONE
CHARACTER? ON THE SET?

>> I THINK YOU'VE GOT TO PAY
HIM.

I THINK IT IS SORT OF, YOU KNOW
--

>> Jon: A LITTLE BIT OF A PARTY
FAVOR TYPE THING.

>> A LITTLE BIT. HE IS
PROBABLY SICK OF DOING IT
FOR HIS FRIENDS.

>> Jon: I LIKE THAT. I LIKE
THAT.

AND WHEN'S, THERE IS GOING TO
BE MORE, RIGHT?  SEASON SIX AND

THE WHOLE THING? OR IT DEPENDS
ON WHEN --

>> I DON'T KNOW WHEN I DIE OR IF
I DIE.

A WOMAN THE OTHER DAY SAID TO
ME, I WAS SORT OF HADN'T
HAD MY MORNING COFFEE YET.
>> Jon: YEAH.

>> AND SHE SAID I HOPE YOU DON'T
DIE.

AND I DIDN'T PUT IT TOGETHER
BECAUSE I WAS TIRED AND I'M A

WRECK BEFORE MY COFFEE
AND IT WAS SO WEIRD AND

IT TOOK ME A SECOND AND IT WAS
SO TERRIFYING.

>> Jon: THAT IS -- WERE YOU JUST
AT A RESTAURANT?
YOU WERE JUST AT --

>> I WAS WALKING ON THE NEW YORK
CITY STREETS AND SHE SAID IT TO
ME IN PASSING.
I HOPE YOU DON'T DIE.

I HOPE I DON'T EITHER. DO YOU
KNOW SOMETHING I DON'T KNOW?

>> Jon: I WOULD LOVE THAT IF
THAT IS JUST SOMETHING SHE DOES
IN THE STREETS OF NEW YORK.
>> YEAH.

>>  Jon: JUST WALKS PAST PEOPLE
AND GOES, I HOPE YOU DON'T DIE!

>> BUT THE THING IS SHE IS
ALWAYS RIGHT BECAUSE WE ALL DO.

>> Jon: SHE IS LIKE THAT FILM
"THE RING."
>> RIGHT.

>> WHEN SHE SAYS IT TO YOU
LIKE SEVEN DAYS LATER YOU'RE
LIKE I DON'T FEEL WELL.

NEW SEASON, "GAME OF THRONES",
PREMIERS THIS SUNDAY AT 9:00,
HBO, THE GREAT PETER DINKLAGE.

comments.text:
Peter's character in The Game of Thrones might just be my favorite 
character in any series ever. I just love when something/someone proves to 
be more powerful than it/he/she seems to be on the surface and I value 
intelligence very high. Tyrion is combination of that, being unexpectedly 
powerful and it stems from his wit. And Peter's acting and charisma is 
amazing. Great voice and intonation and everything. Just awesome.﻿

comments.author: Y Bentley

comments.text:
+Y Bentley What I find alluring about him is that he just seems self-made, 
and confident in himself while sparing true cockiness...he's one of those 
actors who has had to do the "born to do" roles, like being a dwarf in 
Elf...but the guy has the air of a true artist. He wears that on his 
sleeve, and I think Jon just sees too many Hollywood pinup fakes and 
overzealous activists on his show that Earthiness seems foreign to 
him...That and Dinklage doesn't seem as responsive and willing to draw 
attention to himself as a typical Jon guest. Dinklage doesn't seem overly 
willing to entertain here

comments.text: I cringed hard when Stewart referred to the "Mini-Martins".﻿
comments.author: Paul Turbo

comments.text:
+David Hoggan I'm sorry? I do not buy the premise of your analogy.
I'd like to point out that being sensitive of others misfortune when the 
other is well equiped to defend himself on his own is an insult. Because 
you do not trust the 'misfortuned' to handle himself. I would not like to 
get mistrusted.

Calling me thick because I keep defending a view that opposes yours is kind 
of childish, and I merely judge that to be an ill attempt to offend me.
comments.author: TheLineCutter

comments.text:
+TheLineCutter You're awfully thick.  Of course Peter's not offended.  He's 
smart enough to know Stewart had no ill intent. We're just pointing out the 
obvious; it was an analogy presented in the wrong company. Again, no one is 
protecting Peter - we're just discussing one of John's few missteps.  I'd 
like to point out that being sensitive of others misfortunes is also not 
something to be looked down upon.
comments.author: David Hoggan

comments.text:
+David Hoggan It would have been offensive had Jon said: 'Do you happen to 
be one of them'. Then John would have actually made the comparison between 
Peter and mini martins. That would have been awkward and Peter would have 
never been on the show again. But that is not at all relevant yet.
comments.author: TheLineCutter

comments.text:
+David Hoggan nope I think you are oversensative and protective. And it is 
an insult to Peter Dinklage, who in the case that he would be offended 
would say that on camera right in jons face. That he didnt means that he 
didn't take it personally in the first place. Which is how sane people 
handle disabilities.
comments.author: TheLineCutter

comments.text: +David Hoggan  Exactly.
comments.author: Paul Turbo

comments.text:
+TheLineCutter You're wrong.  Stewart made an error.  He alluded to the 
fact George Martin has a group of look alike Dwarves who are  writing his 
book series for him behind the scenes. That's a pretty insensitive thing to 
say in the presence of someone with Dwarfism - especially an actor, as 
their main roles have always been relegated to such fantastical 
stereotypes.  No one here thinks Peter needs protecting.  We're just 
discussing the video...as one does in the comment section of said video.
comments.author: David Hoggan

comments.text:
This shows how messed up some people are. I hold Peter to be a wise man. He 
has been short his whole life. Do you think everytime someone says anything 
that refers to anything being small he will take offence? Mini martins is a 
phrase for fictional workers. He sees that as just a joke and most probably 
doesnt relate it to himself. That you think he would, and try and protect 
him from harm is actually what is wrong here.
comments.author: TheLineCutter

comments.text: +Paul Turbo that's not even offensive :/ at all

comments.text:

comments.text: Why does it bother me that he looks like he doesnt brush his hair...﻿
comments.author: joanne close

comments.text:
+joanne close That bothers me with so many actors and celebrities I can't 
count them, but I did NOT notice it here, I think his mop is great and well 
within "tousled," never tipping over into "looks like he never combs it" as 
so many others do, ESPECIALLY women. Famous actresses march up on stage 
with what literally looks like bed hair, others with gnats and tangles and 
a sticky-looking oily bit of bangs poking them in one eye every time they 
blink. It's beyond unbearable! Look one of these days at Maria Bello in "A 
History of Violence." Her hair is bed hair, uncombed throughout, as if she 
were not a suburban wife and mom, but a bag lady. The look screams of, "My 
face and body are so exquisitely beautiful and timelessly youthful that 
sloppy, thin, greasy, colorless hair actually serves to ENHANCE me!" In 
fact, I once skimmed an article wherein she states that she has never used 
a comb or a brush on her hair in her life. She bragged of it. What does 
THAT say? "Yes, I know, I am THAT exquisite!" And she's believing it all by 
her lonesome.

comments.text:
+Joshua Merrill of course, red hair is technically a genetic mutation, but 
I certainly don't "suffer" from it. :)
comments.author: Emily Jones

comments.text: Lol I like what you did there.
comments.author: Joshua Merrill

comments.text:
+Carly Corday I would argue that doesn't go far enough to empower the 
differently-abled.

That's why I always express myself in positive terms: "He enjoys cystic 
fibrosis", "She is improved immensely by her ovarian cancer", "They delight 
in their mental retardation".

There's no such thing as disability! Anyone who claims that their condition 
is a hardship is just whining, and should be shamed accordingly.

As a loan shark, I envy all the people whose legs I break. How empowering 
that experience must be for them...

*sigh*

If only we could all be so lucky.
comments.author: sarcastic bowl of cornflakes

comments.text:
+Carly Corday According to who? I never heard that before in my life. Who 
gets to decide that its been "dropped" from certain situations, was there 
some press release I unfortunately missed out on? Even the medical field 
doesn't shy away from the word "suffer". It is the most appropriate word. 
It means growth hormone deficiency by the way.
comments.author: Joshua Merrill

comments.text:
Of course not. I hoped you wouldn't just fall back on that for an answer. 
"Suffer" is out of the lexicon for describing genetic conditions that make 
people merely "different". It's been dropped from situations like "She 
suffers from deafness" and "He suffers from cystic fibrosis," and is saved 
more for insults, like "He suffers from an enormous ego" or she "She's 
obese because she suffers from a *wink-wink* glandular disorder." 
"Suffering" implies not dealing with, or incapacity. We want terminology 
that uplifts. What's GHD, by the way? :)
comments.author: Carly Corday

comments.text:
+Carly Corday Dark brown hair isn't classified as a genetic disorder or 
caused by GHD. There sure is a thin line between being fatuous and being 
politically correct these days.
comments.author: Joshua Merrill

comments.text:
+Joshua Merrill It might be incorrect to say he "suffers" from it. Think 
about that. Do you suffer from dark brown hair? Do I?
comments.author: Carly Corday

comments.text:
+Boobalopbop Well, you know, you probably haven't seen that many dwarves. 
There aren't exactly a lot of Hot Dwarf Pageants and Dwarf Idol talent 
searches...maybe there are some real sexy dwarf motherfuckers out there.
comments.author: moonlily1

comments.text:
+Boobalopbop Well he does suffer from dwarfism, so I don't see why it 
should be offensive.
comments.author: Joshua Merrill

comments.text:
+tyler durden Yeah i'm not offended just talking about what most people, 
and I would suspect dwarves, think.  Words have power and meaning or else 
language would just be a whole bunch of sounds thrown together. You're 
right though-they  give power to what you want them to. I have a good 
friend who doesn't mind being called a midget and he doesn't see what the 
big deal is and I know dwarves that can't stand it cause they feel it makes 
them a circus act and not a person.  All depends on the perspective 
someones experience though, I can't  expect someone  to have the same 
reaction because they have different experiences then me. I don't mind 
being called an Okie because I take it as a compliment of being strong and 
having a survival instinct- but some people don't like it cause they think 
they're being called whitetrash. 

At the end of the day best advice I've ever received about being called 
names or other people trying to label you: "Imagine they called you a fire 
hydrant. Because that's going to be as accurate as the nonsense they're 
saying"
comments.author: Tommy D

comments.text: +Tommy D dwarf is okay to use? Iv'e always said little person
